oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Home of C.C.Dodson, Knoxville, Tenn.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Towns, Neighborhoods
African Americans -- Dwellings
Houses; Men; Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Man standing in front of a Queen Anne style Victorian cottage, with other persons: a man at window, a woman and child in the front yard, and a woman at the front door, posing for photographer.

C.C. Dodson was a Knoxville jeweller who had a shop in the Vine Avenue business district. This photograph of his home and family appears to have been taken at the same time as one of Dodson in his jewellery store, one of Mr. Manning's home and one of W.L. Smith's grocery store in Knoxville. This is one of a group of 500 images that were gathered by W.E.B. DuBois and Thomas J. Calloway for display at the Paris Exposition of 1900. The purpose of the photographic exhibit in Paris was to show the history and present status of African Americans. 220 of the photographs are now in the collections of the Library of Congress, including 24 taken in Knoxville (4), Nashville (16), Chattanooga (3), and Memphis (1), Tennessee. The identity of the photographer is not known, but it is possible it could have been DuBois himself, since he was well familiar with Tennessee, having graduated from Nashville's Fisk University in 1888. During his time at Fisk, he taught during summer breaks in Tennessee's rural areas, before continuing his graduate work at Harvard. In 1897, DuBois joined the faculty at Atlanta University and a good number of the photographs in this collection were also taken there. http://www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/anedub/
